q.a: i personally don't like to use roman numerals, because it looks very confusing and it's been a long time since ancient rome. but they're just numbers, for chords. so in the key of C, for example, 1 means C major chord. 2minor means D minor chord, 3minor means E minor chord, 4 means F major chord, 5 means G major chord, 6minor means A minor chord, and 7dim means B diminshed. sometimes lower case number automatically means minor, which i guess is the advantage of the roman numbers because you can use lowercase. but i prefer to just use arabic numbers (123 etc) and just say minor if it's minor. also when i use slash marks that means a different bass note but that doesn't quite make sense for the example you gave so i'm not sure how they are using slashes. also i usually use dashes - to mean minor, but i think in your example they are just being used to separate the chords. actually there are several things about your example that don't make sense to me, but they could be using a different system

q.a: when i was much younger i wrote instrumental music only. then i wrote lyrical music. then i tried to figure out how the entire universe really works (which i actually figured out and forgot simultaneously, which i am still doing, simultaneously ever since) then i decided i wanted to get back into songwriting but my mind was melted (the universe melted it, etc) so i knew i would ultimately be stronger but also weaker at first (due to melted mind) so after a few years of helplessness, i finally decided that any starting point would have to be legitimate, so i started writing the absolute worst / weirdest stuff imaginable, on purpose, just to get started. and i discovered many magical things happening. then i recorded some of it, but i prefered to keep writing more and more and more. then i realized holy crap i'm writing much faster than i'm recording, so i recorded some more. but then i wrote much much much more. then i trained myself to write in a more structured way, rather than just starting from beginning to end crazy style. then i wrote much much more. then i combined the normal catalog with the weird catalog. then i realized holy crap i've written way way too much to ever record. so i wrote more, non-stop, for about a year and a half, this time with a cataloging system of all the existing ideas and fragments, and i was able to go through them and fix them / update them / improve them / fix them, etc. merging all the 'weird' techniques with the 'regular.' and generally got much stronger during that period, and rounded out my skills. then i decided to get them online, but then i realized, i almost forgot, videos are the trick to getting people to pay attention to the songs. so i learned how to make videos

q.q:
One of the few times I have ever experienced something truly different was at a concert a few years ago, when the person organizing everything told the audience beforehand that the foreign instruments we were about to hear would sound strange to our ears, but that they were supposed to sound like that. They weren't out of tune or anything, they were simply from a context where musical beauty is something else than it is here.

There is so much out there, so many instruments, so many ways to make music, that all fall outside what "we" even think of as "instruments" and "music". It feels like an insult to the world when people within a certain context points at something and calls it new or different, when it's clearly derived. It is always derived. Never new, and never different.

This is why your easy-going supposedly theory-defying persona on this page is so provoking. If you had the slightest idea of the kind of superhumanly free innovation everything you say on here is actually hinting to, you wouldn't be saying it, because you never do as you say you (aspire to) do.

For example, you use the word "anything" a lot, as in "do anything" -- yet you basically make music by the book, music that is always somehow firmly rooted in the schools, traditions, rules and conventions of your culture, directly or indirectly. You may think otherwise, but in that case you are wrong. Making music and videos that tend to stand out somewhat in your own narrow sliver of cultural context is no way near actually embracing a theory that says "you can do anything in music". Cut the "anything" crap. It's grandiose and pathetic.

You make great music, but your ambition put into (your own) words is some unreasonable hubris shit.

q.a: keep your eligible song seeds in a list. chronologically by date born is usually the most helpful for me. writing is a different exercise from idea generation, and you basically just need a quiet place where you can do your work. once you're sure that you want to engage in the writing process, some important questions will be: choosing which song to work on, and how far to work on it. during 2012-2013 i had the insane idea that i was going to write just a bit on each one and move on. unfortunately this is not a strategy that will ever lead to completion (because there were hundreds of songs in there), and i worked like that for an entire year and didn't even get close to any kind of completion. (but the good news is i gained worlds of experience, and after that i felt i was a much much stronger writer). but finally i shuffled it up and organized them by percentage of completion and knocked off everything from the 70%s upwards (finishing the writing on those.) then of course you would have a whole other decision making process on which one(s) to record. Another strategy i've been using in more recent years is to make a selection from all the songs (finished or non) and stick with that and complete the writing and recording of that song. this is a good and focused strategy, but the downside is that it can be very hard to feel confident in the decision if none of the songs are beyond 20% written. i guess what i'm trying to say is there are many different strategies for choosing, but the one thing that i'm sure of which i'm trying to tell you is that the writing process is a separate process from idea generation, and you should log all your song seeds into a chronological list, and then go about making a decision on which ones to do and work on writing them. but if you haven't had too much experience in doing the actual 'writing', it might be good to just do a random selection or just go in order chronologically, just to see what goes into the whole writing thing. it's very different from improv/idea generation -- it's much more like being a doctor. you look into the original idea, you make a diagnosis, figure out what it is, where it's going, what it needs, brainstorm on what problems need to be solved, etc, and through hard thinking and trial and error, and a bit of imagination, you can find solutions. it can be grueling for the first few hours but once you have those sweet breakthroughs it can be liberating to know that you can take care of any 'song seed' and take it where it is trying to go. hopefully i've given you some information. as you can see i am still wrestling with some of this myself, mostly when it comes to the song selection strategies

q.a: in general, i usually consider tempos from 60bpm to 120bpm. if it's outside that range you might double or halve it to get it within that range. but another thing usually considered is the snare, if there's a 'backbeat' you'd usually consider that 2 and 4, for example if you were at 110 bpm and your snare seems to be hitting on beat 3 only, you might re-consider the tempo to be 55, so that the snare is on 2 and 4. or if you're at 100bpm and your snare is happening on the "&" of every beat, then you might consider calling it 200 with the snare on 2 and 4. but it gets more confusing because many songs switch to half time or double time. which is where what i call the 'reasonability zone' of 60-120 comes into play. but it's more complicated still, for example in the last couple years i've been hearing a lot of songs with like a super halftime where the tempo is like 60, AND the snare is hitting on only 3. so if you went with the 2 and 4 theory then you'd be calling it 30bpm which is just not reasonable. it's just wherever you think the beat is. wherever you would tap your foot.
q.q: why are only certain drum sounds counted when determining tempo of a drum track? let me explain. Lets say you have a bass drum (B) and a hi hat(H). If it goes HHBHHHBHHHB and so on thats a slower tempo than if the drum track is just BBBBBBBBB. For some reason the hi hats are more seen as something between the actual tempo than the tempo itself. I dont know if im explaining it well. Hopefully you understand.
